QVXX2WzeUmJr3bgbtAlkRQ.text: This review is not for the main restaurant but for the little deli on the side that is known as The Counter at The Delaunay.The Counter at The Delaunay reminds me of an old 1920's style American cafe and serves take-out (or eat-in) "simple" foods where orders can cover hot bacon sandwiches, homemade granola, pretzels, and soup.Although I will say The Counter was very stylish with great attention to detail,  the hot dogs were severely overpriced and lacked any real flavour, the cheesecake (although very light and fluffy) was overly sweetened and they took my very simple order wrong. A great place to sit with a cup of tea, but as someone who loves sweets it is really saying something that I found it a bit much. And this is coming from someone who likes tea with their sugar. Should I come back, it will not be for the food. It will be simply to sit and read a book amongst a beautiful space.

DHr-TXeYYWafH2DeAuf1ig.text: Iwas lucky enough to have a friend take me to The Delaunay last Sunday.Aftera leisurely stroll from my home to the restaurant to clear our heads from arather late night the previous evening, we arrived invigorated and in the moodfor a good hearty brunch.I'dheard mixed reviews about this place but was confident that as it's from the samethoroughbred stable as The Wolseley we were in safe hands. Iwas right! From the off the charming oldgentlemen dressed in his smart green uniform hurried to open the large glassdoors and get us in from the cold. To your left was an attentive cloak room attendantand in front of you  a smiling and efficient front desk who quickly checkedour booking and whisked us off through this wonderful building to our table.Theroom was beautifully dramatic  reminiscent of a bygone age. I felt like I hadstepped into an exquisite silent film set on location in 1930's Paris!Thedark wood panelling, two tone tiled floor, table filled with glass cased cakesand mouth wateringly tempting treats echoed of a lost age of decadence and the crispwhite table clothes set with heavy silver cutlery and art deco sugar completedthe scene, even the napkins were made with an attention to detail not usually botheredwith by most. Wewere seated at a spacious table in a room that can perfectly place all so as toto enjoy the chatter and animation of others in the room  adding to the Frenchfeel of the place.This large open room is as much a visual feast as the menu is tothe taste buds, with choices to suit everyone from its comprehensive brunchmenu from Kedgeree, Black and White Pudding with duck Eggs ,Waffles with mapleSyrup or Bacon, Grilled Kippers and Mustard Butter, Salmon and Cream Cheese Bagel,There was an amazing array of choice of how to have eggs done as well as fishchoices and straight back to Paris with Croque Monsieur and Madame. There wasalso a very New York sounding section with Hot Dogs and Pretzels or you couldcarry on to dishes like the Panino of Grilled Chicken? I could go on and on the menu was really impressive, if you took someone along that could not findsomething they wanted  well I'd say give up  if they can't be pleased here thenthey are a lost cause! The promise to ourselves to not spoil our appetite with bread wasbroken immediately by the smell of the (I'd say rolls but they were shaped morelike strange cactus!) and we dug in and piled on the butter while we waited formy kippers with a side of grilled tomatoes and my friends waffles with maplesyrup to arrive along with a double shot espresso and juices. Delicious, delicious, delicious  the bread did not spoil our appetiteas the moment your food arrives your taste buds scream out for more! I loved it all, from the presentation of the heartshaped swirl in the coffee and the little glass of cold water to cool down yourhot drink if you wished to the cloudy apple juice and freshly squeezed orangeright through to the perfectly cooked kippers with the mustard butter thatbrought together flavours into one of my most delicious brunches ever! As we did not drink alcohol it was extremely reasonably priced  Thequick glimpse I took of the bill before it was sweetly taken from my hand was -Ithink £47 which included service (which of course was discretionary) but I can'timagine anyone ever questioning the service as it was so attentive and charmingwithout being in the slightest bit intrusive. If you want to see pictures andon the spot quick reviews then do go to my twitter accounts @soraya72 or @FoodLovesLondonas their website dos not seem to have a gallery which is a great shame as you don'tget a sense of how beautiful the place is from it. Definitely a place to go for winter lunches and Brunches withclose friends

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

3UWHZC-Rpz5AED1VIiS3_g.text: Elegant atmosphere with pristine service. Had the oatmeal soufflé that was a such a unique and tasty spinoff of a dessert classic. The various eggs benedict at other tables also looked equally as enticing. Expect London prices.

2WtGkLBgt5tKy9Ty4z-7Ow.text: Ate at their overpriced dining room next door, but the prices and ambience here are much better for the same food, so I'd eat here instead, and get patio seating.

LKVe3MYcH2bJNPgs8yIp2g.text: The food was solid and reasonably priced but I had the nagging sensation that I was an extra for a film involving an Axis-occupied restaurant during the Second World War. I found most of the staff to be cold, disinterested and possibly trying to sneak micro-film out in a schnitzel. The pomp and faux- grandeur obviously isn't too everyones taste (clearly not mine) but I am sure a certain clientele will lap up the atmosphere, probably the type that likes Strictly Come Dancing. Don't play it again Sam.

-IM-CYkI0DW8pU-MkqF-Aw.text: Grand Luxe Cafe in Aldwych. Came for a pre-theatre dinner. Room is wonderful and buzzy without being cacophonous like at the Wolseley. Menu eclectic, Viennese cafe fayre. Prices vary wildly. The sausages with accompaniments are very good value at about £8. The Wiener schnitzel pricey at £20 before adding the required side dishes. Desserts vary from patisserie items to wonderful ice-cream sundaes. A great place to slide in and enjoy a dish of something before heading out for the evening or perhaps a casual lunch. Not a great place for a three course traditional meal as the menu is rather disjointed.

4up4Yc8J2OE33UcYJQqYfQ.text: I finally went to try their Sunday roast beef!! I'm not sure they deserve to be on Timeout's Best Sunday Roasts in London list....and unfortunately, the service was quite poor. I don't think I'll be going back. Very classy interiors though.

i5LF8p75EdPBUSeI918nsQ.text: Had a great brunch with friends on Sunday, the menu was delightful, service was wonderful and the food amazing...!

ccW6tViNtuSMrsZm5-sELA.text: The service here is exemplary. The food is excellent, and reasonably priced. Quite big portions as well. Highly recommended.

5oOMC-m7WylSldp51Vk0qQ.text: Perhaps I'm not used to stoic (and/or pretentious) British service and feeling unwelcome as soon as I walk in. Or perhaps I don't enjoy paying £15 for a breakfast which I can best equate to diner food.  Either way, I don't recommend it.

vlY2xnONj7EEJp6HUpZZ-g.text: Really disappointing. Given the location and the fact that its open all day, I was really hoping that this restaurant would be the go to place before an evening at the theatre. Unfortunately this will not be the case. My partner had the braised lamb, which was the dish of the day. It was terrible.I had the wiener schnitzel, which was nothing to shout out about. The fries were not seasoned, and were bad anyway. The dessert: salzberg souffle was awful.A very expensive disappointment indeed.

5Hz92QGdRsx0I0ct9jclkw.text: Definitely meant for tourists and people going to theatre looking for a faux-luxurious experience. Tasted like a mid-to-upscale hotel breakfast in the American Mid-West, albeit more attractive, complete with nicely formed but flavorless pancakes, salty scrambled eggs, wonder bread toast and fruit salad consisting mainly of apples. They attend to service and the mechanics of a good restaurant, but the food is functional at best. There are much better choices elsewhere in London. I would not return.

DO17ze-ifhm4gtWcNp8vSA.text: Too pretentious, I came here for a proper English Breakfast and got it, but didn't our waiter who seemed to snicker at my American ways :).  Loved the Benedict.  Loved the Pain au chocolat. Fiancée had the full English breakfast.  Good food, but I've had better with warmer service ;)

Lil0TeWlLBbNbvJxSeglHg.text: The Delaunay is the Wolseley strike 2, yet another fabulous grand dining hall with a nod to European fare. Think first class Weiners eg bockwurst, Vienesse hot dogs , Tarte flambé (huge but light, cheesy but a little bit porky, perfect), Huge Schnitzels..Basically the kind of fare you can imagine eating in Tarantino's Inglorious bastards with the main baddie in a grand European restaurant. You can dress up in the evening with friends or go casual for lunch or a have a posh work breakfast (if expenses stretch). If you like the Wolseley, you will like this joint. PS go to the Savoy Beaufort bar for an aperitif (just down the road). (monikasays.com )

DTxC72csiqkmzikTj9BFHg.text: gorgeous interior - very upscale, high-end and classy. i came here for breakfast, and right when you walk in, there's an entire table of delicious, gorgeous pastries welcoming you. i had the eggs benedict - very good, and a mini croissant - also very good. their cappuccino is excellent. it came with a foamy heart design and i couldn't help but smile.i'd absolutely come here again if i want to feel pampered and important.note - dress code is fancy. i was wearing a blazer and jeans and i felt slightly under-dressed.

WdNQJ5oLL4qr-XdPCmm3GQ.text: We love the Delaney counter. My husband is a club member close by and we go to the counter for the delicious chicken soup (lunch) or the full afternoon tea, (one of the best in London.) Beautiful surroundings, well thought out place. Thank you!

ACyWiE0V91M3vHUMfr1Ncw.text: I get that unforeseen circumstances happen to both people and businesses alike, but how we handle them speaks volumes. We had a reservation at The Delaunay for today, Easter Sunday. There was apparently a fire nearby, and it knocked out power to the restaurant. Disappointing, for sure, but we could have dealt with it fairly easily, if informed. However, The Delaunay didn't contact us to tell us of the closure, not a call (we have a European phone number), text or email. We found out by walking up to an obviously closed restaurant with a printed and laminated sign telling us that they were closed. There wasn't even someone from the restaurant there to tell us or direct us to other places to eat. I've worked at restaurants that had to close unexpectedly for the day, and I was there to man the phones and greet people and inform them of the closure. Really, you could even do that? We won't be back.

HMmRdLelGI-88Gjg97uYyg.text: What a beautiful dining experience!  We wandered in on a whim on a Thursday evening during a busy dinner time and were fortunate enough that they could accommodate us, though in the bar.  It was still lovely and fun and interesting.  Lots of nearly famous people wandering around, and a discreet note on the menu that no photography was allowed, which says something about their clientele, perhaps?  Sure, it's pricey, but my spatchcock chicken (yes, I did say spatchcock) was lovely and well prepared.  The same goes for my friends' calf tongue's and sirloin steak.  Our waitress was a little bossy and a little lax on filling our pitcher of water considering what we were paying, but it was still better-than-average service for the UK, and so I can't truly complain.  It really was ALLLL about the dessert, though.  Overpriced?  Yes, probably.   But o so very very very yummy!  YUM-MEEEE!  I recommend the Kinder.  LOTS of beautiful things all mixed together in one amazing massive lovely dessert.  I'd totally go back here again for the right occasion if I wanted to spoil myself or someone else.

akWLWV0iSFJj2B4XtAsGSQ.text: This is my new favourite place. I like the space better than the Wolseley; it feels like it was born to be a restaurant whereas I sort of think the Wolseley feels a little like a repurposed bank. The menu is perfect for breakfast or lunch - I haven't been there for dinner but for me it's more of a fun, daylight kind of place. It's similar to Bob Bob Ricard but better because it's more lively. I loved the look and the menu at BBR, but it never seemed to have quite enough people. The Delaunay seems to be successfully full but not crowded, and it feels interesting without being pretentious. The whole sausage / hot dog section of the menu is cool. And I really like it that they give you a newspaper to read while you wait for the rest of your party to arrive. If you like the idea of taking a stroll into 1930s London definitely give it a whirl.

-9AOQ1YmspL0C-sNJAyLhw.text: The Counter at the Delaunay is hugely disappointing.  It looks very attractive and it's a lovely place to while away a spare half hour (newspapers provided) and convenient for Covent Garden in the evening.  But, and it's a big BUT, the food is miserable.  A friend and I shared two plates of mixed salad which were tasteless and fiddly and there was no dressing to be had (only big squeezy things of mustard and ketchup which really don't replace a nice vinaigrette).  I'd heard good things about the sacher torte so we shared a slice, and a strawberry tarte.  The tarte was fine.  The sacher torte was a disaster.  It wasn't even a decent piece of chocolate cake.  Greasy bland icing over oily crumbs of dark brown sponge which barely tasted of chocolate can hardly be described as sacher torte.  And the 'French Valhrona' hot chocolate was a teaspoon of chocolate powder in the bottom of a huge glass of steamed milk.  Call me fussy but if it says 'hot chocolate' I expect it to be not just hot, but actually taste of chocolate. Had the food been excellent, I would have swallowed the prices (£7 for the salads I think, and about £4 for the puddings) happily, but given the miserable offerings I was quite upset about the total bill of £25.I won't be returning which is a real shame given the location and ambiance.

Hrdnu0dJdvMqrvxZ1tj3vw.text: Food was great, decor was ridiculously overwhelming and way too much. That would be my sum-up of this lovely restaurant. Well, that would be easy, if I could just get away with just one sentence. However, I know my fellow yelpers would want more so here goes. I ordered the Beef stroganoff which was so filling and there were several flavours overwhelming and overlapping each other. The mixture was interesting, yet delightful. They also have lots of other dishes, prepared especially for you, my carnivore friends. There's lots of pork belly on the menu and you really can't go wrong with any of its options.

1mmQbunCqdKbTYA3HRPjiQ.text: This is a fantastic place - pick up delicious pastries and cakes and enjoy excellent coffee at the "Counter". Haven't tried the proper restaurant yet, but at the counter you can also get good lunch (I like the chicken schnitzel) at decent prices (around 6 quid for the schnitzel). I love the place - not least because of its Viennese charm.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Bar

x9jK6xW5lnJ1likc4_7dRg.text: Get the coffee to go if you want something besides Starbucks. But, get the food at Eat or Pret...

WpUXK00XO07Sqd2453aF5g.text: Amazing, stupendous, spectacular! I took my mother and her friend here for a birthday dinner when they came to visit. We were also going to see Beautiful: The Carol King Musical that night so the location was perfect. When I made the reservation on line I had made a not that we were celebrating my mother's birthday hoping they might do something special, which they did, in the form of a cake for dessert that included a plaque saying "happy birthday.But first, when we arrived I noticed the door man standing near the door. It was only after I opened the door for myself that he came over and held the door for the res of my party. We were seated promptly but waited maybe a good ten minutes before anyone came over to take our drink order. But once the server arrived we informed him we were ready to order everything he sent over his "associate" to take our order. The food was AMAZING! I had the sea bass which was excellent, perfectly cooked and a side of summer vegetable. My mother ordered the stroganoff which was to die for. She couldn't eat it all so I helped and it was by far the best beef stroganoff I've ever eaten. Our friend had the ribeye which she said was also very good. I ordered the truffles for dessert because we were all so full, and I thought maybe that would be served with a happy birthday message. But no, they gave my mom a complimentary piece of decadent chocolate cake. The truffles were sinfully good. It took about 5 minutes and 3 bites to get through one! That intense! The moment that really nailed it for us was when our friend spilled some béarnaise sauce down the front of her shirt. The waiter noticed and without saying anything brought over an extra napkin and club soda in a bottle. A female server saw this and came over with a glass for the club soda and made a joke about men not knowing how to handle stains. It was a wonderful experience. Yes, it is expensive, but you get what you pay for. Excellent food and excellent service.

WAkAuevgi20azwJDjXZUYg.text: We really enjoyed a light pre-theatre lunch at the Delaunay Counter. I loved my bagel with cream cheese and smoked salmon and he happily ate his Reuben sandwich with pastrami, sauerkraut and cheese. We like The Delaunay and we will no doubt be returning when we want something with a little flair.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. The Delaunay Counter

XQvNF-S_2hIrm4tbLWAvkQ.text: I went here for lunch at the counter on a cold February afternoon. It's always the lights that get me. Warm and dim and reflecting off so much brass that I can't see the opposite walls.. that's what I want on a cold day.The counter is cosy, and the food is high quality, although for the price and reputation you do expect more. My hot dog was nice and tangy, but a bit small and a little unsurprising..Still, the room is lovely, and when it's snowing outside and you have a nice spot in the corner with a newspaper it's difficult to leave.I just kept ordering pastries and coffee. I tried to claim squatter's rights but they forced me out eventually. I'd been there for two weeks...

rwPsysUkV0mM_euGX2ifVQ.text: Honestly my unsexy as hell sounding 'prune and cognac' tart was so good it alone could have earned the 5 stars. I spent 3 hours loitering over dinner with a friend, and loved it. The atmosphere was relaxed but beautiful, the waiters were friendly (even though they did make a few mistakes, which were quickly rectified), and the food was old school Viennese meat and heavy veg in a beautiful way.My only niggle was when I said I didn't want another bottle of sparkling water, and the waitress came back with one, began pouring it and said "Well I thought I'd bring you one anyway" It was a very strange overbearing thing to do....!That said I'd definitely come back, it felt ridiculously glamorous and I loved my weiner wrapped in bacon, stuffed with cheese: could you GET more ridiculously awesome than that? No.

LwlvQ1BnYJ3PZ_OH2PlLyA.text: Went again, drank loads, and this time had a perfect schnitzel.Chips, mashed potatoes, and salad were similarly excellent, as was service.

W5SbGLogA8S7H6teZIyo8Q.text: I came here for afternoon tea with family who were visiting London for the first time, and it was a really lovely place for them to take in the tradition.We arrived a bit early for our reservation and started with drinks at the bar -- I had the Warsaw martini, which was delicious. After being seated, I ended up ordering the cream tea (I tried the Delaunay blend for my tea, and I'd recommend it as a pretty safe option), while my brother got a bagel with smoked salmon and an Americano (can you tell we're from New York?) and my mother had the Welsh rarebit. Everyone really enjoyed their choices; my mom the coffee-hater even had positive things to say when she tried my brother's Americano.Aside from the food, we enjoyed the general ambiance, and the service would have been wonderful if it had been just a bit less slow. It was also quite reasonably priced for the quality of the food and experience, and it's seemingly much easier to get a reservation here than at other places of similar caliber. Would recommend.

OkXcT6i9msxRse1DAW8rgg.text: The Delaunay has been on my hit list ever since I got wind of the Wolseley's latest sibling, and last night's dinner did not fail to wow. There was definitely a case of the giggles when we reviewed the various menus - Crustacea, Shcnitzels, Weiners - thought the stunning ambiance, somewhat of a mix between an old worldly brasserie and a romanticised trans-Siberian train, made the whole experience feel very proper, though a somewhat unusual choice for such seemingly unrefined food.All the food was excellent, as were the drinks, and I would definitely be going back after an evening matinée, or some musical in the area that I never end up seeing. If the restaurant was more in the likes of Mayfair, or Knightsbridge, I would much more likely frequent it regularly, as I don't find myself on the Stand too often, unfortunately I don't think I'll find myself back here anytime soon.

7HeXpdyFrGJz-dFjYs_KRA.text: This is a very nice-looking place on Aldwych, a short walk up from Temple tube station. It looks like a grand dining hall I imagine from the 19th century. The staff are all in crisp uniforms and the service is well-honed.  It looks like a good place to bring young children: we saw a few tables where the whole family had come out for Sunday brunch. It's a kind of high dining restaurant for the family.We were sitting at our table before our meals arrived and I thought to myself how relaxed and comfortable I was in that setting.  It would have been nice to have a slow coffee and chill out.  However, we were here for brunch.  We were told that our reservation gave us a two hour slot and I found this to be more than enough.  (Although, I usually don't really like it when you are given a time limit with your reservation.)We each got a marrochino which was a shot of espresso with a wafer of dark chocolate.  You drop the chocolate into the coffee, then stir to create a mini mocha of sorts.  At least, I hope that's what your supposed to do.  It was nice, but pretty small.I was in brunch mode, so I got the pancakes with bacon. My wife got the Arlington: a toasted English muffin with poached egg, salmon and hollandaise sauce. It looked very nice, and the muffin was toasted enough such that the toppings didn't make it soggy.  We shared a one of the cakes from the display near the entrance to finish.  My wife was raving about it.  Well done!They made a mistake with the bill, including something that we hadn't ordered.  But this was quickly cleared up without fuss.  They also have a cover charge of £2 per person (I think to cover the free bread which they give you at the start).  I also usually don't like this, but I won't let it dampen my review of an otherwise good experience.

uWqnKCRb2xspfyKYRZySag.text: Very good food, good quality, higher prices but not a rip off.Very posh and guests can be a bit snooty.The serving staff are definitely on commission to sell more food and can be a bit sly about how they do it.

nyQNFHzi4xVsVrP47pNirA.text: Beautiful restaurant, good food and friendly service. Came here twice for dinner with my parents when they were in town and they loved it. Great place for date night as well.

TcnvVy4W0QrGRgZAbuRPNA.text: Ok this place falls on a great location .. The food selection is decent. Food quality ranges between average and above average, the biggest problem here is the service. Slow and inconsistent. It took 35 minutes to get the check. It took another 25 minutes to actually pay. Had it not been for the slow service this place would have earned a solid 4 stars. I was not there in a busy time came in at 2 o'clock got out at 4:15 by the time I paid the bill.

Y-SkzCgqZCswVLgGomLuYg.text: Came here with a friend from back home, and chose this place cos I wanted to bring her somewhere classy and amazing. True enough, this place is indeed classy - loved the interior, and the atmosphere was was lovely. We went on a weekday morning so most people there were people doing srs bizness - it was amusing cos for a period of time we were the youngest people in the restaurant and it was rather awkward because it made us seem either we were a) unemployed or b) rich kids with a lot of daddy's money to spend.The breakfast is definitely on the pricey side - we ordered an All English breakfast to share with a mini-pastry basket. I ordered a regular macchiato (that came in a super-tiny cup - the waitress did warn me but i didn't know it was THAT small ) and my friend ordered her usual mocha. The food met expectations - nothing really spectacular on that side. I felt that my money mostly went into the interior, the cutlery, the service and the experience. If I had more moolah I'd definitely go back again but this time to their pastry section because the pastry looked amaaaazing - so sad I didn't get to try them all.  One day. When I have more money. Till then, Delaunay!

YVn5Qlr-BS5NwkVbd1-6uw.text: We had a wonderful dinner here and look forward to returning.  After the delicious wursts (with sauerkraut and potato salad) and schnitzel we were too full to finish everything else.  The atmosphere was cozy and romantic for a date night but it definitely seems like a good spot for groups as well, given the size of the restaurant.  The service was great for us as well.

TiJJQ2oWo6LYgHUUzaxBSg.text: Went for dinner on Saturday night. Was In a group so tried a variety of items on the menu. All disappointing. Nothing special until the dessert (kinder was surprisingly good). However, service was decent. Even still, I would not return.

jLMLwAUiLTXwDioI3juqCg.text: Afternoon tea review:Gorgeous venue but absolutely packed, had to shout to be heard but the person sitting next to me. We ordered the afternoon tea for 3. Received a nice selection of sweet and savoury however there was only one or two of each item, which resulted in us having to ration who could have what. Overall there were around 18 items which sounds a lot but they were of course all miniature so it barely filled us up. And it was nowhere near worth the price of over £70. I was shocked they had the cheek to charge us that much with the amount of food they actually gave us.

yXT8qe8u9rlMgdvrPfzyxQ.text: went again and brought my friend for a cup of tea. Got desirable table place and had lovely tea and cakes.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

5fGj8n3byc9htvhONnsbcg.text: With so many other/better cafés and patisseries to be found, I can't recommend wasting any time seeking this place out - all attitude with no substance.  The assortment of baked goods was disappointing - with a fraction of what you could find at much smaller places like Paul's or Patisserie Valerie, for example.  And having tried an assortment of what was on offer, I found it all tough and flavorless.  To top it off, I had to wait and wait and wait for any kind of service - most annoyingly to track down someone to finally bring my bill.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

ng9pXD2EZ2q8_buZ-Lo5KQ.text: My friend wanted tea and The Delaunay was in a convenient location so we decided to give it a try. The vibe of the place was really awesome - I'd say it's kind of vintage. Anyway, there were hardly any other people there at around 9 pm so there were plenty of seats available. I ended up ordering a pot of green tea, which came out within 5 minutes in a cool-looking teapot. Unfortunately, I wasn't impressed with the actual tea. It just tasted bitter, without much of the flavor that green tea is supposed to give. Even though the price was relatively low - 2.15 pounds - I probably wouldn't get the tea here a second time.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Green tea

1xuG2OqVgifDMtwj1gsxwQ.text: Good Viennese style coffee for a meeting. Not cheap. And I hear the food is good. Gorgeous inside.

teCTVJ8RA789nJhdiVmdRg.text: You know I quite liked this place. Part of the same group that is responsible for the  Wolseley, I expected the good service, and the elegant surroundings. In many ways I liked the atmosphere better here as it felt a bit more European old world, back when this area of London near the Savoy were the most elegant parts of the city, and now sitting at the Delaunay with its chic patrons you feel like that is true again. I wasn't sure how I'd feel about the Viennese, meat heavy menu, but here again what is old is new. I had a delicious, quite grand, Alsace style sauerkraut that was a treat. Everything from soup to nuts was well done -and I was having lunch. Definitely a place to go for something special, even if that something special is that you are in the mood for something nice.

1iAXxxgMH7z1R2cyUvkKfw.text: Had theater tickets to see Top Hat our last night in London, looked around the web for something close by before the show. The Delaunay, 55 Aldwych London was literally across the street and has received good press. Well deserved press as we had an excellent pre theater dinner. Didn't want to be too full so skipped apps. DW had the Wiener Schnitzel and I had the Braised Shoulder of Lamb white beans and paprika sausageWe shared sides of buttery mashed potatoes and wilted spinach. Everything perfectly prepared and flavorful. Apple & Walnut Strudel with vanilla ice cream finished off an excellent meal.PS: Top Hat was was a great show. Next stop, Paris!

tsLrMjopO0uXNpAqB2S8ow.text: This place rocks. Situated on the epic Strand. You walk in and immediately feel under dressed, so don't bother fancying yourself up unless you're committed to a black tie!  "I feel so under dressed was THE most overheard statement all night. But why?  It's beautiful architecture and decor, arrangement of seating and art like performance of service. The food is too notch. Dead the menu for fun then speak to a waiter to get something you might not have been brave enough to just order. For me, schnitzel cordon bleu, the house "brew" and a side of pickled cucumbers. If you want to have fun, don't order for a while ... I was catching up with friends after work and thought we relax and chat a bit. We had reservations and it was about half or less seated.  Over the next twenty minutes we saw every waiter, and two levels of management, when we were finally informed, "I w(v)ill take (z)your order (n)now!"  Really loved it. Dark  Chocolate truffles were amazing too.

hn5shmJb1CP4Z3447YT3Ig.text: We went to dinner at the restaurant based on a recommendation. I would describe it as up scaled German street food and French (and some German food listed in French, just to be confusing).  If you are looking for an upscale hot dog, look no further. The restaurant is lovely, as is the service and presentation. I expected more from the food. The cordon bleu (I thought it was odd that it was listed with the schnitzel, but I guess it is breaded meat) was good. All of the flavors were there and the sauce did not cover everything up, nor did it need to. The choucroute a l'Alsaciene (german sausage, french title) is a variety of the sausage (a huge portion of sausage) with a large portion of sauerkraut (too much) and a couple of potatoes thrown in. This is enough for at least a couple of people who are really into their meat, but not so much the potatoes. The sausage was good, and it was very rich, It was more of a standard good, not outstanding good. The beef stroganoff was better, the sauce had a good flavor.

ZP5WOOLtB1bMNY89nXdlAA.text: I love The Delaunay, it is one of my favorite restaurants in London.  The decor is lovely and the service is impeccable.  They have a fantastic European menu (the schnitzel is divine!).  I also love the elegant table settings.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Schnitzel with butter mash

lJ_6h66gyzHMIkuqKjJXjw.text: This review is for the Counter.I was feeling a bit under the weather and was enticed in by the sign of chicken soup for takeaway. While waiting in line to order I had a vew of all the cakes and was very tempted to buy all of them! After my order was taken it took about 5 mins to have my soup in hand. The soup was homemade. Tasted like something my grandma would have made, with real bits of chicken and mini noodles. The bread and butter were really nice as well. Everything was very good, but for the price I would have expected a bit more chicken, noodles, and maybe even some carrots or something in there.

GjLE6Lvs42b842qaIzEYjQ.text: Stopped in for a quick coffee and I wound up having the torte of the day. The place has a beautiful, classy, old-world ambience and pleasant service. The torte of the day was simply amazing. Unfortunately, I dug into it before I could get a picture. It was a heavy cream cake with perfect pie crust and a small bit of (real?) gold leaf on top. It was the best pastry of our trip. Service was a bit on the slow side, considering that they weren't busy.

l7DoOSMPob6fuKfQbO2a0Q.text: Items Selected:Drip CoffeeAlmond CroissantCherry Almond MuffinPancakes with Fruit CompoteCrumpets with Strawberry Jam and Orange MarmaladePistachio Lemon Mille FeuilleDobos TortCoffee and Stroh Rum CakeOwned and operated by the group behind The Wolseley and offering an equally grand café to the well-heeled and well-dressed of Covent Garden it was at The Delaunay that my Wednesday morning began and although lacking the stellar black pudding and canele of its Piccadilly sibling there was more than suitable solace to be found both on the menu and at the attached "Counter" next door.  Open from breakfast to dinner with fanciful tea service in the late afternoon it was minutes to eight when I arrived at 55 Aldwych and again favoring foyer seating to that of the bustling main room it was mere moments before a man arrived unannounced with coffee, something I'd not ordered but certainly planned to - the full pot turning into a gift as the party who'd made the request had apparently moved on.  Truly a fine space with service befitting the locale and a menu of compelling scope it was once again to an almond croissant that I turned but fairing similarly to the soft version at The Wolseley it was not until a replacement was requested that something suitably crisp arrived, another gift with it in the form of a warm muffin bursting with fruit to 'make up' for the gaff.  Intentionally trending carbohydrate heavy as I continued breakfast with a plate of pillowy pancakes topped with stewed persimmons and raspberry reduction alongside buttery crumpets and a duo of jams it would not be long before I finished and with the bill delivered on request I gathered my belongings only to find myself soon seated again, an Austrian trio of The Counter's cakes each proving to be of impeccable quality with the rich Dobos Tort rousing memories of my Hungarian heritage and Grandma's cooking in ways far too rare.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Pancakes with Fruit Compote
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Pancakes with Fruit Compote
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Pancakes with Fruit Compote, Crumpets with Strawberry Jam and Orange Marmalade

sJ7Z2pgCtm6Uz0ddFAiLlw.text: So disappointed! We have loved this place since its' opening and as we were going to London for the weekend, eagerly booked a table. We booked with top table for us and 2 friend who were local. They had never been to the Delaunay.    Even with the reservation they struggled to find a place for us. Finally, we were given a tiny table that half jutted in the foyer and half into the dining room. The table was so small we struggled to find places for our tea and coffee. I eagerly order the pasty basket 8.50 which was a hit on the last visit. Well, this year it was so small, not even two of us were able to share it.    We sat for a long time, finally hailing down passing servers to place our order, get water. Every need was a begging request. We were never greeted, I am not sure we had the same person twice.     Fortunately, the entrees were just as good as last year but the experience was terrible and embarrassing. We conveyed our disappointment to the host on the way out were told "Oh really, so sorry... bye."    I think they Delaunay is unfortunately becoming a victim of it's own success.

H8Yt0XxNSufTRiY4cz4gDA.text: Came to Delaunay's for the first time a few months ago while visiting London. The place is a very upscale restaurant with a beautiful dining area and bar. I ordered:Rib-eye Steak and fries - the steak was perfectly cooked to medium rare. it was juicy and delicious. the fries were also good but nothing out of this world.But the best thing I got to taste was a bite of the Fillet of Sea Bass. It was one of the best pieces of fish I've ever had. Perfectly cooked and fresh. Soft while not mushy. It was unreal. So, my recommendation is if your in London and fancy an upscale meal....head to Delaunay and order the sea bass. You won't be disappointed.

HOBc9VzJqiNyJ0xKjB-_Ug.text: Positive: Interesting menu, pleasant decor, good serviceNegative: Prices on high side, ambiance spoiled by some of clientele who on day of visit skewed towards the "Braying Hooray" archetype ...

i6qFRAgjXIvJ1Nynlon5Yg.text: My second time here was slightly disappointing -- not on the food end, but more on efficient service! I had a flat white and a cheese/tomato croissant in-restaurant (highly recommend the croissant -- I had it toasted and can't talk about it enough! Reasonably priced for something of that quality in prime real estate in an expensive city). However, I came in and was told I could sit anywhere to be served -- perfectly fine. I wanted to sit outside and knew that there was a risk I'd be overlooked or ignored (they do have busy outside seating but I'd come a bit earlier than the outdoorsy rush typically sat outside). It took me a rather long time of staring intently over my shoulder through the cafe window to flag down a waiter to take my order (which I'd made up the instant I walked in). Then, a different waiter brought out my flat white at last, but had a moment of carelessness in which my drink was roughly plopped on the table (I acknowledge it may have been an accident, but that's still not good for business) and the flat white spilled, with some liquid seeping into my textbook....After a brief moment of awkwardness, the waiter realized the proper thing to do was to remake the flat white -- in the same soiled cup. I don't normally care, but I'd expected more from such a fancy and well-known establishment, I guess! Still, the waiters were relatively friendly and attentive after that -- so same rating! But perhaps a word to the wise: sit inside or explicitly tell the staff you'll be outside.

UrSs0yvx1wjxgk72GiQTgA.text: Good brunch - albeit slightly overpriced - in an atmosphere reminiscent of a cafe in Vienna.However, I really didn't like the £2 cover charge that wasn't explicitly mentioned on the menu. We asked to have it removed, which the waiter kindly did, but I think this charge shouldn't be there in the first place... If you go to the Delaunay, make sure you check the bill and avoid being ripped off.

pEPBBhQPrQpTyHFU5NeltQ.text: First, the hostesses is not fit to be in hospitality business, very rude and unpleasant. We got the worse table at the Resturant even though there were plenty others available, and her excuse was we made our reservations late. And yes the other tables were still empty when we left. And for food it was okay, not something I would come back here for but also would not avoid but the hostesses has to go.

Vny4YedepdKzg78Z3WY0LA.text: Great place for brunch as well as afternoon tea. Reasonable price and really good environment.

qlhEVSrJx90T6pnHFHE0wA.text: The service was excellent, the atmosphere was classic London and the food was delish.I don't usually write reviews but I wanted to write this one in particular because of the excellent service we received while there.It was a very small gesture but I remember it months later.We had ordered the pastry sampler platter (highly recommended) and were disappointed to find out one of the many pastries we wanted to try wasn't on there. We asked the waiter about it and said it did not include the particular pastry. Before I could say I'd be willing to pay for it, he said not to worry, he would go get it for us and not to worry about paying for it.A small gesture like that is really what makes good restaurants great.

nhrsf2XLIZFGS584AnKnnQ.text: Had coffee and pastries here, both of which were good, though not mind-blowing as other reviews make it seem. What makes this place worth the cost is the old world decor, mild-mannered service, and the generally sedate ambiance. Put another way, it's like a living, breathing antique store. Worth a visit.

5TLCYQkzS3IGNm41_hQzaQ.text: I was told by good friends who used to live in London to try breakfast at the Wolseley  --it is a must!  I was swayed by a foodie relative to instead try their new sister restaurant which had just opened to rave reviews, the Delaunay.  The space is uber fancy, beautiful, in the style of an old European cafe with well-turned out waitstaff throughout the restaurant, white table clothes, old world dark woods, white tile floors, white tablecloths, elaborate place settings, and a beautiful oak bar.  There is a cafe with buffet style foods next to a formal restaurant.  We ate in the restaurant.We walked in for an 11:30 breakfast without a reservation on a Thursday, and were promptly seated in a half-empty dining room.  The dining room was stylish and traditional: it was gorgeous in an old-school (but modern) London way.To be honest, it was a shocking poor service experience.  There were almost 20 waitstaff, and they all looked exceedingly dapper, but we were surprised to find they paid more attention to promptly decorating empty tables in elaborate settings than servicing the very few (time of day) customers in their establishment.  We had multiple servers, but never the same person, so they seemed to forget who we were and what we needed. For instance, our crumpets arrived without butter or jam, and as they cooled on the table we tried to flag someone, anyone down.   By the time they cooled, the butter had finally arrived and then we asked for jam, and were told it was not included: they would have to charge extra.  Did we still want it?   Um, yes!  All I could think is why were we finding this out now: why had no one thought to ask if we wanted butter and jam when we ordered crumpets 15 minutes before?We ordered tap water later to find out later, when we asked, that it was filtered and we'd be charged 1.5 pounds for it, but (lucky us!) it'd be refilled for free throughout the meal.  Gosh, not that that's a big deal really, but being charged extra for things like water and jam, and well, you start to feel like the hospitality factor is somewhat lacking.The lattes and coffee we ordered were strong, tasty, and served beautifully.  There is even a tiny cup of water (to wash your spoon in? Fancy!) and a chocolate to enjoy with it.  Here, things were generous (as long as we weren't charged extra for that lovely chocolate, because I'm starting to wonder...)The meals our party had were all good: waffles with bacon, kedgeree (my first time, but the curry was NOT subtle making it hard to taste the smoked fish), and an order of pancakes.  All were solid offerings.There seems to be a market in London for a place that does a good breakfast, but even more of a market here for an overly fancy place.  By the feel of the place, should be five stars.  But its not: you don't ever feel comfortable here or well looked after.  I think if they can figure out a way to not charge "convenience fees" for things like jam or water, and just roll it into the price, we'd have felt like we were having a better experience, overall.(I must give credit that by end of the meal we did have a full apology from the captain of the dining room, along with a break on the bill.  This was a nice gesture and certainly appreciated.)

QDD0V6piJJgISqIYxzug0g.text: I was just here to order the crumpets I saw pictures of on Yelp but they were not here. They said it is a special order with 48 hour notice? Wtf. Byeee

rEjLRV8sNGLlicyL8fg2Qg.text: The Delaunay reminds me a lot of The Wolseley. I still like the food and decor better at the latter, but this place isn't bad. We were here for breakfast. While it's famous for its classic English breakfast, The Delaunay also has a wide variety of continental breakfast items (French pastries, Vienna style coffee, etc). Our waiter was very attentive and polite. No complaints about the service. The location is great. A few minutes walk from the Temple station, near LSE and Covent Garden, perfect for having a large fancy breakfast and then walk it off in Covent Garden shops nearby.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Smoked salmon with scrambled eggs

ATv6NvStCPDdoUIIvR--iA.text: Quite possibly the best French toast I ever had. The place looks amazing. Cappuccino, beautiful. Very happy to have found this place. Next time I am having salty breakfast.

aylh3z0meMAg1HVvg8Y5Ow.text: This a very nice restaurant in the theater district. Very upscale looking interior, beautiful décor.The menu is a very interesting mix of many style comfort foods with a German/Austrian flare.The service was very good. Nice wine list with an excellent selection of Italian wines.I had the specialty hand made sausages with German potato salad and kraut. Rockstar had the Eggs Benedict.Nice experience finished off with Amoretto Coffee.The rating average was pulled down by the 2 star rating from someone who drank tea but did not experience the food.

fXq_DLYGzSQIeQJqmLAqvg.text: This is a rather elegant restaurant with very good food and a very good wine list. It is open late at night, so can be visited after theater performances, which is what we did.  The atmosphere was pleasantly low-key and the service very professional.  My only reservation is that the cost is higher by about one-third than that of other restaurants of the same class in the same area.

nRnb2vSprWTF_OqF18Ln6w.text: If you ever want to impress someone, take them here. Don't go in the plebian entrance - you want the one on the corner of the street or you'll be redirected through. Anyway, imagine an English Balthazar with all your standard British fare done..just, well, just done right and extremely well. Saying that, the oatmeal souffle (souffle? for breakfast!?) is superb. The service is absolutely top-notch, leaving me completely alone -- basically how I judge service these days to be honest -- until I realised I wanted to leave. The only thing that prevents a 5-star review is that the tea was £4.50 - this seemed a little out of place compared to the rest of the prices weren't that mad and I felt that irrational price pang there. Although it does keep the riff-raff out. Good riddance.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Oatmeal souffle with berry compote.

Juy6mkx50WI59SeOmccvNQ.text: Went for a full-course dinner, and everything was lovely. I ordered the beetroot salad for starter which I absolutely enjoyed. It was fresh and served in healthy portions. Then, I ordered the chicken schnitzel. It was solid and a big portion as well, but I made the mistake of ordering it without any sides -- be sure to order something with it if you want to enjoy it to the fullest! Ambience was posh and sophisticated. Perfect for dinners with beloved ones on special occasion. Finally, service was also prompt. Well-trained and knowledgeable staff to pamper your throughout your meal. All in all, a great place, and I'd be happy to go back!

Gz4y2r7wdfBGSzx5GAFKsA.text: Absolutely excellent! Server was attentive to our time constraints due to theatre tickets! Hamburgers were cooked to perfection! I chose a dinner salad and was pleasantly surprised at the variety of vegetables included! Gorgeous European old world charm! We were pleased to find this venue is the sister to the Worsley on Piccadilly! The corner entrance made one feel special!

QPLdp5VJWZ30o8mLTwDHoQ.text: Re. the Counter: wonderful atmosphere, but found both a piece of plastic and then a small insect in my food. Didn't complain bc I didn't want to play the loud American, but when server got my change wrong by ten pounds, I did complain.

MYQUxVwD_cZwo63v48f9lw.text: Bruch visit on 31st Dec. We were able to get a table around bar area immediately. Schnitzel and eggs were really good. Would visit again soon.

_NTjWLd5VGNQG8D9rKcI1Q.text: The food was delicious and surprisingly large portions, so much there wasn't room for dessert!Borscht -- large portion, and tasted great Duck breast -- so tender, so flavorful. And the spinach purée was an excellent touchOysters -- fresh and tastyScallops and prawns -- lovely seafood flavorLiver wurst -- rich

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Scallop and prawn
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Duck, with spinach puree
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Borscht, ordered cold

zgBPWLIyhwad8xR5f26oYg.text: Excellent food & service!  We were very pleased!  My husband had the Fillet of Beef Stroganoff and I the Chicken Schnitzel with the Grilled Vegetable Salad--YUM YUM YUM!

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

og1Z9lCPWWugfDpmuizZpQ.text: Went for an early breakfast one morning and our meal was great. I ordered the pancakes with blueberry compote and an English Breakfast tea. The other person in my party ordered one of the egg sandwiches. Both were delicious. The portions were large and the tea was strong.The service was prompt and professional. We were dining in a hurry and the waiters took our order and brought out our food quickly. The atmosphere felt very sophisticated, as there were all sorts of business people having early morning breakfasts and meetings. Remember to dress nicely!

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. pancakes with blueberries and creme fraiche & english breakfast tea

arofY0i91JFlZ5iwNYRabA.text: Excellent atmosphere inside/outside. Like having a coffee in Paris! Nice cappuccino/great for breakfast.Try sausage sandwich or croissant with cheese/tomato. Even the music is so relaxing...

sjgGdVwc7yG_jVXWY6xZrw.text: Came here for bookclub brunch and was pleased with the service and food. The space itself is quite dignified but there was adorable half-Japanese moppet running around and they were graciousness itself with him. I would thoroughly recommend the rosti - huge portions and satisfyingly presented, if a teeny bit greasy. The girls who had the avo-on-toast were also very happy. Would totally return with a posh adult if I was in need of classy surroundings!  Especial kudos to the lovely staff!

VxV-oI47X7UubL3zGxl-Eg.text: We were looking for a place to get brunch and our hotel recommended the Delaunay!  I ordered this amazing omelette and got to pick my additional ingredients. My girlfriend is vegetarian and they actually have a separate vegetarian menu!! We were very impressed!  She had a delicious lentil soup that was very flavorful. She also had the eggs florentine which melted in your mouth!The wait staff was extremely attentive and very helpful! We didn't have room for dessert but their dessert presentation looked scrumptious!I loved the ambience and wish that we had time for dinner.  Next time!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Dessert table
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Cappuccino art!
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Eggs florentine

vpBZWXIFWRQVbpnPtkXd8g.text: Came here for an early breakfast without a reservation and was eagerly seen to, even though it was already filling up. Inside is beautifully set and a generous amount of space given between tables.I ended up going for the Omelette Arnold Bennett which was incredible. Eggs slightly scrambled in a bowl that must've been put under a grill to crisp up the top. So when you dive, in it's still a bit runny and creamy underneath. Would highly recommend. (Visit 03/07/2015 Breakfast)

1fjCrfMszEXlw6RweLf-XA.text: It's a really unpleasant experience with the restaurant. My wife and I came into the restaurant about 8 pm and did not have our entree (main) until 9:25. People who came in later than us, finished their dinner and left the restaurant before our entrees were ready.We asked for extra bread while we are waiting for the entree. But it took 30 min to get the extra bread.Our entrees are burger and filet, I still cannot understand why it took so long to prepare for them.

6fJZ6lhpI56c6M0z2L6BHA.text: This place didn't blow me away but served its purpose - which was to go for a nice Friday brunch with the girls on the morning of our best friend's wedding reception (helpfully leaving said friend by herself to do any final prep - woops). As sister to The Wolseley, it has that same 1930s-Europe-inspired grand brasserie feel - think marble flooring, white linen tablecloths and smartly aproned waiters. You definitely feel like you're somewhere a bit swish, so it was nice to find that the breakfast prices are still pretty reasonable for such a setting.We arrived deliberately just in time to order from the breakfast menu (served til 11.30am on weekdays btw, so max out that lie-in!) feeling like we were bunking off school as we'd all taken the day off work. There's a good amount of choice and my Potato Rosti with Fried Egg for £5 was really filling (you get 2 eggs). Think I was happier than my friend who chose Eggs Florentine and got half the food for twice the price. We always do the 'double brunch' as standard though, following everyone's first round with 2 orders of pancakes to share between 5 of us (defo go for the blueberries and crème fraiche stack). The Tropical Fruit smoothie also gets my recommendation, and if anyone else out there has a strange love of unusual kitchenware (err yep, that would be me) you'll enjoy using the tea strainers ;)The service could've been a bit warmer; the woman on the door looked quite unimpressed but then we did load her up with a lot of dress bags to put in the cloakroom. Otherwise the service was civil if a little slow given we'd hit the late morning lull between peak breakfast time and lunch. This also meant we were making most of the noise in the place for a good part of the meal (not surprising for us) so wonder if there's more of a buzz at busier times.The food didn't stand out enough to rush back, but for a weekday girly brunch it did just fine.

brA5cA6hBDI_9K2Zywk5hg.text: THE PLACE TO GO FOR TEA in London!!!Such a wonderful experience, I am looking for something similar at home. The service, the food and the experience was the highlight of my trip to London.

R4wwXR_cN6VknJw-xzer_A.text: Excellent service and foodTry the snitzel (breaded chicken) - just wonderful and light. The bread comes warm and fresh.The restaurant is not noisy and the ambiance is excellent!It is worth to walk to this place - the neighborhood is very cool.Even the bathroom soap has a very nice fragrance. Really recommend it - not a tourist trap in London.

swrumw-dGBcT1y8-grrxhQ.text: If your craving the right schnitzel than you r at the right place The avocado salad , a bit dry Go for the beetroot tartar nicer Cheesecake and apple crumble was very good

1L6Hfgzwaut0zHs0VxVKjg.text: The girls and I ate at "The Counter", which is like the less fancy part of the establishment. The service was very hospitable, and we liked the atmosphere, despite the oppressive heat of another mid-80s day.We had Stiegl beers, which were cold, and the fondue to start. The fondue was delicious, with cauliflower and toasted bread bits. The cheese was gruyere, but lacked brandy, and had a ring of butter around the edge signaling that it could have been hotter. Still tasty.Wife and I each had the schnitzel and potato salad. She is German, and we've eaten a lot of this stuff, in Germany, Leavenworth WA, Austria, and at home. We agreed that this schnitzel was just okay. The meat was nicely cooked, the perfect thickness, and had no gristle. The breading, however, reminded us of cheap fish and chips. It lacked dimension in both flavor and feel. It was simply breadcrumbs--bland. But the potato salad is where they really dropped the ball. It was nice small potatoes, cut in half, and covered in--special sauce! It was the french fry sauce served in countless small town burger joints throughout North America! So, if you expect the cucumbery vinegar and onion tang of what we call "German potato salad" you will be out of luck.Still, for fair prices and great service, you could do worse.

HIZcpO-pCwLx-iO1UMCgIg.text: One of the many places in London to get a sitdown breakfast. The coffee was great, the bread basket for the most part perfect: the butter croissants and almond croissants were a dream, but the toast was a bit off and rubbery. Butter and jam/marmalade to sweeten the deal for a durable start into the day.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

B_JKmNCya00UmDXSRD-lUQ.text: Great food! The fish and chips were great. I enjoyed the chicken schnitzel. The chips or fries were average. The salad was very fresh and tasty.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

F24jwueu4S_3Se1PGHEmEA.text: Had an exceptional experience here trying my first Afternoon Tea. I am visiting from the US and was looking for a beautiful tea experience for my birthday. Everything was delicious and beautifully plated. I highly recommend! Also, if you get the opportunity, you should try both the scone and Gugelhupf, both very tasty!

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

mem795a3HkK-lc9-9dSn0g.text: My wife and I came here for High Tea and it was really good.  The atmosphere was buzzy (a bit louder than we'd hoped), but the service was very good. The tea was delicious and the accompanying foods were great -- we got the Poppy Seed Gugelhupfwith apricot jam and whipped cream as well theFruit Scones with strawberry jam and clotted cream.  We highly recommend the Scone with clotted cream.The savory food was also delicious -- especially the one with ham and cucumber.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

gw1IYveb5S5ktsivuA8OqQ.text: Went for afternoon tea before a Broadway show. Service was great, food wonderful and the restaurant is lovely. Highly recommend

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

eEXXEmSzzYTqriOXMn8PwQ.text: We went for lunch here while we were recently in London. The interior is very nice with lots of wood and the display counters were filled with lots of delicious food. They seated us very promptly. They have a very nice menu with lots of soups and sandwiches and small plates. We ordered a quiche with a salad and tomato soup with rye bread and wine. The soup and bread was delicious just like your Mom would make. My husband liked his quiche and the service was excellent. We ate here twice on our stay and enjoyed it a lot. They also had great looking desserts.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Quiche and salad

19pD1tG27qASJT88wwH5cA.text: We were visiting London to see my brother who was studying abroad there. Since he had not done the "Afternoon Tea" experience, my research took me here to the Delaunay.Yes, this place is certainly upscale. It is "pink up" fancy. I almost felt a bit out of place but I knew what to expect as I have done other afternoon tea type experiences. For 20 or so pounds, I think you get a pretty good tea experience. What it includes is a tea selection/tea pot for each individual as well as a selection of sweet and savories such as little canapes, scones, etc. I thought I would love the savories a bit more but they left something to be desired. The sweets were quite good and came with whipped cream. The scones came warm came with a clotted cream and jelly which were quite good. Waiters were attentive and brought refills of hot water for the tea pots.There were two nut allergies that we advised the waiters on. They sent a manager to personally speak with us about the accommodations they were making to prevent giving us anything with nuts. While this was a great experience, there was some confusion when the sweet and savories came to the table, the waiter mentioned pistachios on some of the desserts to which I had again reminded his that pistachios were nuts...The waiter left to go get the manager leaving us with the food that we were afraid to start on until we had more clarification. There was quite an awkward lull/wait until the manage came to explain that the "pistachio" items were actually "mint cream" but did not outwardly recognize that he had misspoken or made a mistake when explaining what was on the trays. This was a small hiccup but it did make my brother a bit nervous as he was the one with the severe nut allergy. Everything was fine though as he tried every item and did not have any reactions to the selections. A few others around us were having afternoon teas as well as others were having either late lunch or early dinners. It was a fun and different kind of experience but I think I would try another spot next time I am in London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea

263fyOQnLA2D3s20HoKixA.text: A lovely piece of Mittel Europe,  right in the middle of London's West End:  formal service, dark clubby Viennese atmosphere, an excellent wine list and surprising good cooking.  It's also open late,  far later than most establishments of any quality,  so perfect for a decent meal after a theatre, being on the Aldwych just minutes from the Strand.  Their menu is online, not particularly large, but what they do they do well: in particular my rib-eye was outstanding:  large, perfectly trimmed, cooked rare as requested, juicy and perfectly seasoned, with excellent crispy chips and more bearnaise than even I could manage, which means a lot!  Prices are middling, but given the location & quality offer very good value, though wines from the excellent list are not cheap, with very little under £30.  Professional in a good way, European in a good way, this is a good place right across the board.

dHCvQPSM3HXCBBH4OTZvZg.text: Now. I can't actually remember what I ate here... it was very fancy and the service was top notch. As expected. All I can remember eating though is the desert. We got the Salzburg soufflé, impressive and an experience, but it does just taste like apricot egg air. We also got the banana split. Which was disappointing. The chocolate sauce was super rich and over powered everything. You go for the experience more than anything.

5-wQ9XiumaFSPfceDttL_g.text: My friends and I had brunch here and it was a great solid place! I ordered the Fried Duck Egg (8/10, tasty and on the slightly above average heavy side) and a Green Smoothie (Didn't taste good but did the job of "refreshing" me haha). My friends ordered Eggs Florentine, Eggs Benedict and Steak Tartare (They liked their dishes). The ambiance of this place is conducive to a casual conversation, even while the place is large and usually decently packed. Great solid brunch place. Definitely would return!

2D1Or9z3hOTB-gMwzeo9FA.text: I have had dinner here a couple of times - always excellent - and recently did my first brunch visit. As with its sister restaurant the Wolseley the highlight of the delaunay is the atmosphere. You do feel transported to a bustling day in Vienna. It is such a great mix of high quality yet relaxed. The food and the service are both fantastic. I enjoyed the pancakes for brunch and had an excellent flat white - a 7 out of 10 on the coffee front. This really is a restaurant for every meal. And the location is also great - we did brunch here before heading over to Somerset house.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Mmmm proper salted butter

sg7dNB1a3chqgvJIpiglSA.text: European style old charm coffee and tea parlor.Have dinner menu as well.We came for coffee and pastries. Cappuccinos, Sacher Torte, Pain au Chocolate, Croisants, etc were delicious.Service was corteous and prompt.I wanted to go back for the schnitzel.Wien, Wien nur du allein...

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Cappuccinos
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Ham & Cheese Croisant
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Cappuccinos

b2rk8MVipaKqZ8WBAh2H4w.text: Dined here last night with my daughter and was very impressed by the interior , service and food .My daughter had the spatchcock chicken w a wonderful salsa verde with just a touch of chili flakes intermingled with the ultra green parsley sauce . I had such wonderful Irish oysters as a starter that I ordered a second round . My main was the veal schnitzel and was perfectly crisp with lemon on side and a darker sauce on the side that was subtle but delicious . And then banana split to share for dessert . Our waiter Michele from Italy was attentive and a pleasure to interact with. I will be sure to visit again on any subsequent trips to London .

JUDlwlGgutPXRPxR2YZMJA.text: This restaurant was recommended to us by the concierge at the Savoy and I'm glad he told us about it. I liked several items on the menu and couldn't decide so I asked the waiter for suggestions and he mentioned that the Stroganoff was one of their specialties. (and it was one of the things I was considering) It was wonderful! So tasty! The service was also very pleasant. I also liked the dark wood cozy atmosphere and I felt the prices were reasonable. Very convenient if you're going to the theater, too.

gSVGfJ6f0mHi130_ZTfs1w.text: A great place to have a pit stop near Theatreland in Covent Garden. The cafe serves a delightful chicken schnitzel and a mean millefeuille. A tiny bit pricey but lovely surroundings.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom

WRwI0O9sc1Wxul3qWck0og.text: Must go to for breakfast or lunch. A gorgeous place to be. Lovely ambiance and friendly service. A different scene from all the hipster brunch spot popping up. This takes you back to a warm traditional interior. The food is good and the fresh juice of the day was excellent. Ordered the Arnold omelet. It was unique bc never had it before, but it was a bit mushy and wet in the inside for me. I poured a lot of tabasco bc there wasn't much of a flavor and taste to it. But it was still lovely! Would recommend this place. You are given a specific amount of time to dine, but after eating, I suggest to go to the cafe connected next door for some coffee and or dessert.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Viennese Breakfast, 11.50
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Omelette Arnold Bennett, 11.25
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. Omelette Arnold Bennett, 11.25

86e5qnsvGSj5L9BEFCnhwQ.text: Ever walked in to a restaurant and felt totally under dressed? Well, I'm not I'll ever feel properly dressed for The Delaunay!Situated close to Temple station, the grand entrance of The Delaunay will make anyone feel like a superstar. Our bags were swiftly taken by someone in exchange for a small numbered token, and we were taken to our table. We had reserved as we were a table of six, but there were plenty of other large tables around, so they were very accommodating. Service is done in a very traditional manner, with an individual of the team taking each section of the order and then delivering it. Our drinks order was taken quickly, then presented a little while later - a slight delay, but probably due to the cappuccinos taking longer to make, and their desire to ensure everything arrives at the same time.I had a pot of breakfast tea, served with a small tea strainer; the novelty of having 'proper tea' was initially slightly lost on me, though I enjoyed the theatrical nature of having a little implement to strain the tea leaves. The menu is larger than expected, though we were focused purely on the breakfast/brunch section. They appear to be known for their eggs benedict, which many of our party went for, but I opted for the pancakes with blueberries and creme fraiche. They were served in a perfect stack, with a layer of blueberry compote between each individual pancake; pancakes come in many forms, and these were some of the best I have had. The aforementioned layer of compote meant I didn't have to experience that slightly dry final few mouthfuls of many previous meals elsewhere, and there was enough creme fraiche to last for the whole stack. I was also presented with my own little jug of maple syrup.As a final flourish, my ever adorable parents (yes, that's you mum!) had mentioned my upcoming birthday, so I was delivered a little plate of lovely morsels upon the bill arriving. Strawberry and lemon homemade marshmallows were zingy and fluffy, and turkish delight - mum's favourite! - went down with a smile.A real treat for when you're looking for something really special.

photos.caption: Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. proper tea (2014)
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. blueberry & creme fraiche pancakes (2014)
Photo of The Delaunay - London, United Kingdom. birthday treats (2014)
